If anyone is getting confused, knowing all of the kinematic equations helps a lot. In this problem, since you have the initial velocity of the tennis ball (0 m/s), the acceleration (g), and the time (1.7 s), and you’re trying to find the distance (delta_X), you can use the kinematic equation delta_X = V_initial + 1/2 a t^2 and plug in the values to get your answer. This way, you can solve many (even complex) physics problems, even if you haven’t taken (or don’t understand) calculus! See the physics videos on Khan academy for more info.

Great video! However I would like to point out that there is a faster method : you explained that velocity was the integral of acceleration and that position was the integral of velocity. There are no easy general formulas for integrals, unlike derivatives, which makes them far more complicated, even if derivatives have the powerful rules of the chain rule and the power rule; when you have complicated substitutions, multiplications or divisions, it’s just long, but you can arrive to it with those 2 rules; it’s not impossible, it’s long and sometimes boringly monotonous.  Actually, those 2 rules are precisely why integrals are so difficult; you can’t just work the 2 tules backwards to find antiderivatives; have you guys ever tried that ? You’d think about a combinations of functions that lead to the one you’ve started with when applying the rules, but then those same rules lead to unwanted terms to which you’ll need to create other terms, and so-on....that’s why we have the u-substitution, the DI method, another kind of substitution that involves making t equal to tan(x), I think, which is useful with trigonometric integrals, bla bla bla...  So I’ll recommend you guys Blackpenredpen (yeeeaahh !!!); he’s THE ONLY ONE interesting enough when he does math and, most of all, calculus, including Dr. Payam  And I’m in Sec 5; I’ve only known calculus in school from my sec 5 physics teacher BECAUSE he was getting ahead of his curriculum to prepare ourselves for CEGEP (I’m Canadian, btw, hey) ! And he only did simple derivatives; I’m about to learn more about vector calculus; all because of YouTube (and Blackpenredpen, yeeeaaahhhh !!!!; you’ll understand the yeahs if you look at his videos, especially at the end)

To get the estimated total area of a curve from under the graph you use the most basic shape that you know how to calculate the area of, a rectangle (recall that the area = length * width). If you draw an arbitrary amount of rectangles under the graph and add their respective areas you get an estimated sum. So, if you take an infinite amount rectangles and add their areas you get an exact amount. Hope this helps.

I know you can't just teach everything there is to know about integrals in a 10 minute video on youtube, but right at 00:20 I found something that, not being exactly wrong, it's completely misleading.  Yes, an integral will give you the area between the curve and the horizontal axis BUT (and it's a big but here), those areas under the horizontal axis (that is, the vertical axis has negative values) will count as "negative area" (I know, I know, an area can't have a negative value, but bear with me).  What I mean is that the values for the different areas under the horizontal axis will be subtracted from the values of the areas above said axis. For example, if your equation between points A and B has 5 area units above X and 3 area units below, if you just do the integral from A to B, that will give you 2 as a result instead of 8. To do it right you first have to see if A and B have positive or negative values and find all the different Pn points in X ( A<=Pn<=B) in which f(Pn)=0 (or, in an easier way to understand it, all the points in which the curve "cuts" X, that is, when the value of the curve equals zero).  So, you would actually have to calculate the integrals for the intervals A-P1, P1-P2, P2-P3, ..., Pn-B, which will have (in an alternate fashion) positive and negative values. You will have to change the negative values into positive ones and then add them all together.  Other than that, nice video, maybe the example wasn't that clear to begin with but, nice anyway.

At 4:40 and 5:44, your claims about the constant of integration only apply to certain cases. Many position functions in physics include expressions beyond simple polynomials. This seems more complicated than it needs to be. You genuinely don't care what value your speed is at any given time, what you need is the speed function. You also don't need to drag around C all the way back into the motion function. You can resolve it as soon as you find the speed function. A single constant is trivial to resolve as long as you know the function value for a specific value of the variable. We know the speed was 0 at time 0, so C is 0. Integrate the result again and you get the motion function with another constant. We know that the location was 0 at time 0, so you can weed that out, as well.  f(0) = 0 f'(0) = 0 f''(t) = 9.81  f(1.7) = ?  f'(t) = ∫f''(t)*dt = ∫9.81*dt = 9.81t + C  f'(0) = 0 <=> 9.81*0 + C = 0 <=> C = 0 => f'(t) = 9.81t  f(t) = ∫f'(t)dt = ∫9.81t*dt = 1/2(9.81)t^2 + C = 4.905t^2 + C f(0) = 0 <=> 4.905*0^2 + C = 0 <=> C = 0 => f(t) = 4.905t^2  f(1.7) = 4.905*(1.7)^2 = 4.905*2.89 = 14.17545  Mind you, all of this is assuming our graph is upside-down. With cartesian coordinates, g would actually be -9.81, since it would accelerate items "down" while the y axis (which is what we're using here to determine "height") is positive in the "up" direction and negative in the "down" direction. Technically, the "height" of our window from the origin point of "us" would be -14.17545m, meaning the ball ended up ~14 meters below us.

+Hamzawi Somthing To be explicit, both Newton and (independently) Leibnitz developed calculus in the 1600s.  For Newton this was because he needed it in order to prove his work on forces and gravitation (specifically he needed integrals to show that for a uniform density body you can consider all the mass to be at its centre, and then derivatives naturally also dropped out of that).  Although we usually decide to credit Newton with the invention of these pieces of calculus we use a notation that is closer to that of Leibnitz.

+Mohamed Nedal Redefine your acceleration as positive. That won't change the absolute value and you can isolate (t). Negative acceleration is arbitrarily chosen by which direction you define as negative. Say a car can go either east or west. East being positive and west negative on a position graph. A negative acceleration would indicate the car went west. You use the absolute value of the acceleration to isolate the variables you don't know (say time and distance traveled) and then at the end you put your negative mark back to say the car traveled -212m or whatever.  In reality the car will always travel 212 meters. You can't really travel a negative distance. In real life that just doesn't make sense. That negative is just really there because you can go in 2 opposed directions on an axis and they had to have the math represent that in some way. Sometimes very useful. But when you need to do a square root to get (t) just get rid of it, temporarily...

I'm sorry, but she is mixing up indefinite integration with regular integration. Int(a dt) is not vt +C but v(t1)v(t0). The integral calculates not the velocity but the change in velocity thus therefore you have to put a v0. more correctly and closely related to differentiation: v(t1)=v(t0)+int(t0>t1,a) which becomes v0+at if a is constant and t0=0

A lot of the confusion could ve been prevented by explaining what the power rule is i think:  To get the derivative of x^2 it becomes 2x The power number if put in front of the variable. And the power number is taken down a point.  So, 2x^3 becomes 6x^2 Because (2*3)x^(3-1) <-- the power number multiplies the number in front of the variable, and the power number is taken one down.  Say we have the following equasion: x^2 +5x Then we basically apply the same rules. It may help to read that equasion like this: 1x^(2) +5x^(1) So the result is: 2x +5 Because (1*2)x^(2-1) + (5*1)x^(1-1) An power to 0 or x^0 = 1 so in math/physics we can leave that out. We tend to leave out 1s anyway where possible.  Taking the integral just works the way back. 6x +9 becomes 3x^2 +9x Because the new power law goes up from 1 to 2, the factor number before the variable must be devided by 2, and so it becomes 3 (because taking the derivative of the result should produce the initial starting formula). The constant number 9 can be read as 9 = 9*1 = 9x^0 9/1 * x^(0+1) = 9x^1 = 9x  As for the formulas above, just consider this: If i take the integral of speed, i get the distance. One can calculate that distance by calculating the surface area below a speed graph. If i take the derivative of speed, i get the acceleration. I can calculate the acceleration by calculating the slope of the speed graph.  Hope it helps somebody...

+Anthony Tefel  Because not everything moves at constant acceleration. For example, imagine you want to find the position of a ball at the end of an oscillating spring, but the only thing you know about it is that the force on the ball changes according to the equation k·sin(π·t), where k is some constant.  Suddenly it's not so easy to find it's position from it's acceleration. However, using calculus, we know the velocity would follow the equation -k·cos(π·t)/π. We take the integral of that to find the position, and we find it follows the equation - k·sin(π·t)/π².  Pretty useful if you ask me.

+AkujiMalice A curve is a series of infinitely tiny lines, but the angles between the lines must be free to vary. As you approach an infinite number of lines, the angle between any two lines approaches 180 degrees.  In the approximation of a circle which demonstrates that π = 4, the lines are always kept at right angles to each other, and thus the sum total length of the lines does not approach the circumference of the circle like they would if you allow the angles to get wider.

+Firefin3 At 3:10, the 2 in the denominator comes from the 1+1 in the exponent on t. You need to divide by the number in the exponent because otherwise you wouldn't get the same equation as the one you started with if you took the derivative. That is to say that if you didn't have the 2 in the denominator, the equation you get after integrating would be 2t^2, and the derivative of 2t^2 is not 2t.   At 9:07, I think you must have forgotten to square t. So you probably calculated 0.5*9.8*1.7 instead of 0.5*9.8*1.7*1.7.

+Mistic Mike When finding a primitive function(antiderivative or whatever) in general that is correct (especially when the function have a set of conditions like; F(0)=1), but you don't need +C when calculating integrals.  Let's say we have f(x)=2x+1 than the primitive function is F(x)=x^2+x+C and if we wan't to calculate the integral within the x-values:0 and 2 we get; (2^2+2+c)-(0+0+c)=6+C-C=6. It would of course be different if the function already had a constant. f(x)=2x+1+c which gives us F(x)=x^2+x+Cx+D and the integral with the same x-values; 6+2C

+Silver Mirai Fundamental theorem of calculus;    Integral from a to b f(x) dx = F(b) - F(a) , F(x) being an anti-derivative. This gets rid of C, saying as the antiderivative of a function at any point will have the same C, so we subtract to cancel it out. What we are left with is the accumulated area under the curve. This is so much more universal than all the rules she talks about, and the second part of the fundamental theorem of calculus states the the derivative of the integral from a to t of f(x) dx = f(t). The second part basically states that the derivative of an integral is the function. Goddamn, they need to show you this theorem on crash course. I guess we'll have to wait until crash course math. :P
+Silver Mirai Also, they never mentioned the anti-derivative of the power rule; if f(x) = x^n , then the anti-derivative F(x) = (x^n+1)/(n+1). Very useful.
